properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall continuing today and tonight. Rain will continue through the day today and into tonight before easing to light rain Wednesday morning. Rain will linger Wednesday and into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Additional rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm over most areas are expected by Wednesday morning, although local amounts exceeding 50 mm are possible. Environment and Climate Change Canada continues to monitor the situation. Rainfall warnings may be issued as necessary. Rainfall warnings are issued when rainfall amounts of 50 mm or more are expected in 24 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-24T07:14:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-23T15:15:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4186618038.2020
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, Gogama - Foleyet, Kirkland Lake - Englehart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain continuing today and tonight. Rain, at times heavy, will continue through the day today and into tonight before easing to light rain Wednesday morning. Rain will linger Wednesday and into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Additional rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm over most areas are expected by Wednesday morning, although local amounts exceeding 75 mm are possible for a few locales. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-24T07:12:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-23T15:13:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4185066936.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls, Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of very warm and humid weather is expected. Time span: today through Thursday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 37), except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 16 to 18 degrees Celsius. Locations: much of western, central and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate for the next couple of days. Temperatures are expected to turn cooler Friday as showery weather arrives. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please call HealthLine 811 for advice on health risks, symptoms and precautions associated with heat. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-06-24T10:19:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-23T18:20:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0709718098.2020
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warm temperatures in the days ahead for inland areas of Nova Scotia Time span: tonight to Thursday. Minimum temperatures tonight and Wednesday night: near 18 Celsius. Maximum temperature Wednesday: near 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 36). Locations: Annapolis Valley through northern Nova Scotia Remarks: Warm weather with high humidity is expected to continue on Wednesday. Some areas may see relief from the heat on Thursday, but warning criteria is expected to be exceeded again on Thursday in the northeastern counties of mainland Nova Scotia. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-24T10:55:26-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. Some severe thunderstorms may develop near the Alberta border this afternoon. These storms should weaken throughout the evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-24T04:47:25-00:00

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke is causing poor air quality and reducing visibility. Smoke is expected or occurring. High levels of air pollution are expected today due to smoke from forest fires. The smoke plumes from forest fires in the Chute-des-Passes area may affect neighbouring regions. Air quality could deteriorate if the smoke mixes down to ground level. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. If your home is not air-conditioned, be sure the house doesn't get too warm when doors and windows are closed to keep out smoke. Exposure to too much heat can also result in illness. People with lung diseases, such as asthma and COPD, can be particularly sensitive to air pollution. They will generally experience more serious health effects at lower levels. Pollution can aggravate their diseases, leading to increased medication use, doctor and emergency room visits, and hospital visits. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-06-24T06:59:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-23T15:00:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3536968334.2020
Area: Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Tropical Storm Dolly. This is the only information statement planned for this storm at this time. Tropical Storm Dolly formed in the waters well south of Nova Scotia late this afternoon. The Canadian Hurricane Centre continues to monitor Dolly and it is not expected to have any direct impact on Canadian land areas. Tropical Storm Dolly was upgraded from Sub-tropical Depression Four earlier this afternoon, based on measurements from satellite wind sensors. Despite this slight increase in intensity that brought the system to tropical storm strength, Dolly is forecast to weaken later tonight before it enters offshore Canadian waters Wednesday morning, It is expected to become fully dissipated later Wednesday night or early Thursday. Forecaster(s): Borgel ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-06-25T02:43:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-23T20:44:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1871337366.2020
Area: Guysborough County, Richmond County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County

properties.Summary:

Locations impacted include: Gravenhurst, Bracebridge, Huntsville and Baysville. ### Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 33 are expected for the next 3 days. Warm temperatures continue. Time span: tonight to Thursday. Minimum temperature tonight and Wednesday night: near 18 degrees Celsius. Maximum temperature Wednesday: near 29 degrees Celsius (Humidex 37). Locations: Prince Edward Island Remarks: Warm weather is expected to continue again tomorrow with temperatures near 29 degrees in the afternoon. Some relief from the heat is possible over western Prince Edward Island on Thursday, but warning criteria is likely to be exceeded again on Thursday in the east. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-24T10:55:06-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and torrential rain. Hazards: - damaging wind gusts near 90 km/h - torrential rain giving 50 mm in an hour or less Locations: Leeds and Grenville County, portions of Lanark County and areas east including the National Capital Region. Timing: Late morning into the early evening. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-06-24T03:09:40-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 6:04 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, pea to dime size hail and heavy rain. This severe thunderstorm is located near Morrison Lake, moving north at 35 km/h. Locations impacted include: Gravenhurst, Glen Echo, Morrison Lake, South Muldrew Lake, North Muldrew Lake, Muskoka Bay, St. Elmo, Muskoka Beach and Muskoka Falls. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 4:33 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing strong wind gusts. This line of severe thunderstorms is located from Waubaushene to New Lowell, moving north at 25 km/h. Locations impacted include: Elmvale, Hillsdale, Port Severn, Edenvale, Orr Lake, Orr Lake, Waubaushene, Little Lake, Gloucester Pool and Black Lake. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain continuing tonight. Rain, at times heavy, will continue tonight before easing to light rain Wednesday morning. Rain will linger Wednesday and into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 75 mm are expected by Wednesday morning over most areas. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
